    • Method Detail

      • findSentiment

        public double findSentiment(java.lang.String s)
        Find sentiment of a given input string s. Follow this guideline. - Eliminate all full stops, commas, semi-colons from s. You do not need to check other punctuations. - Separate the string into words using whitespace characters [ \t\n\x0B\f\r]. - Count the number of negative words in s. - Count the number of positive words in s. - Count the number of stop words in s. - Count the total number of words in s. - Compute the sentiment score using these counts. - See how to do so and the examples in the assignment description. - Use getProperty() to get the reference to the Property object. Obtain the array of positive words, negative words, and stop words using the methods getPositiveTerms(), getNegativeTerms(), getStopWords() of the Property object. The scoring method is obtained by calling the method getScoringMethod() of the same Property object.
        Specified by:
        findSentiment in interface ISentiment
        Parameters:
        s - Input string
        Returns:
        0 if s is empty or the stop word count is equal to the number of words in the string Otherwise, return the sentiment score computed based on the choice of the scoring method.
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if s is null IllegalStateException if the member variable keeping the reference to the Property object is null.

      • findCount

        public static int findCount(java.lang.String[] wordArr,
            java.lang.String[] tokenArr)
        Count the number of words in tokenArr that match the words in wordArr.
        Parameters:
        wordArr - Array of positive words, negative words, or stop words depending on what you want to count
        tokenArr - Array of words
        Returns:
        0 if wordArr is empty or tokenArr is empty; otherwise, return the count of words in tokenArr matching those in wordArr.
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if wordArr or tokenArr is null

        public boolean equals(java.lang.Object o)
        Override equals as discussed in class. Consider both name and property when comparing the objects. Your code must not break if the reference to the Property object is null.

      • showSentiment

        public java.lang.String showSentiment(double score)
        Show text sentiment for the given sentiment score.
        Specified by:
        showSentiment in interface ISentiment
        Parameters:
        score - sentiment score
        Returns:
        "Positive" if score >= the predefined distance threshold obtained by calling getMinDistance() of the Property object "Negative" if score <= -1 * the predefined distance threshold "Unknown" otherwise
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if the member variable that keeps the reference to the Property object is null.
